docs.lead_paragraph: L ARRY O'BRIEN was looking very relaxed, indeed very commissionerlike amid the simple elegance of his office 15 floors above a bustling and breezy, cold Fifth Avenue in midtown. Outside, darkness began to cover the view of St. Patrick's Cathedral to the south and Rockefeller Center to the west. A hectic day was nearing an end. So, his head was back, his collar and tie hung loose and his feet rolled lazily atop his slightly cluttered desk. There was reason for O'Brien's cheerful mood early last week. For, despite the f act that seven of the National B asketball Association's 23 teams were presently registering decreases in fan attendance from last season, the league-wide figure was up al most 10 percent, with nine teams showing increases of more than 1,1 00 fans a game. Also, the league recently signed a new network tele vision contract with theColumbia Broadcasting System, which reportedl y calls for the teams todivide a total of $88 million in rights fees over four years. That represents an increase of about $14 million o ver the previous payout.

docs.snippet: CBS is negotiating to sell its Fawcett Books Group, apparently to Ballantine Books, the mass-market subsidiary of Random House.  Neither party would comment on the reported sale, which has been widely rumored for two weeks, but lawyers for both si...
docs.lead_paragraph: CBS is negotiating to sell its Fawcett Books Group, apparently to Ballantine Books, the mass-market subsidiary of Random House. Neither party would comment on the reported sale, which has been widely rumored for two weeks, but lawyers for both sides were trying to hammer out final details yesterday, and a formal announcement was said to be imminent. ''This is just the latest confirmation that the paperback industry continues to be financially hard-pressed,'' one paperback executive said. Concern Over Reprint Sales At the same time, CBS has talked with Richard Gallen, president of Richard Gallen Books, about selling him its Popular Library imprint, which it acquired in 1971.

headline.main: CBS TRYING TO SELL FAWCETT BOOKS TO BALLANTINE

docs.snippet: A PERENNIAL   Samson Raphaelson started writing for theater and film in the 1920's (''The Jazz Singer'' wa s his first cre dit in each), and now, in his 80's, he has a new - well, almost new - unpublished play that can be heard in a reading at Col...
docs.lead_paragraph: A PERENNIAL Samson Raphaelson started writing for theater and film in the 1920's (''The Jazz Singer'' wa s his first cre dit in each), and now, in his 80's, he has a new - well, almost new - unpublished play that can be heard in a reading at Columbia Univers ity's Horace Mann Theater, 120th and Broadway, at 7:30 P.M. tod ay. The play, ''Here We Are, Alone Together,'' was written about 10 years ago, and the reading is part of an evening's tribute to him. Sylvia Sidney will be host of the proceedings, which mark the start of a festival of new playwrights' workshops by Columbia's School of the Arts, produced by Andrew B. Harris for its Oscar Hammerstein 2d Center. Only a week ago, Mr. Raphaelson showed up with Miss Sidney at a screening of ''Accent on Youth,'' which he wrote and in which she starred and whose name is being applied to the festival.

docs.snippet: Guerrillas hijacked a Colombian airliner today and forced it to fly to Cali, where they released 47 of the 128 people aboard.   The plane then crashed into an army truck during an attempted takeoff. The authorities reported that the rebels threate...
docs.lead_paragraph: Guerrillas hijacked a Colombian airliner today and forced it to fly to Cali, where they released 47 of the 128 people aboard. The plane then crashed into an army truck during an attempted takeoff. The authorities reported that the rebels threatened to blow up the plane if they were not given another one.

docs.snippet: THE United States Department of Agriculture is expected soon to adopt a regulation that will allow the meat industry to include bits of ground-up bone in processed meats without labeling it as such. If the regulation is adopted, it would be the la...
docs.lead_paragraph: THE United States Department of Agriculture is expected soon to adopt a regulation that will allow the meat industry to include bits of ground-up bone in processed meats without labeling it as such. If the regulation is adopted, it would be the latest move in a fiveyear-old controversy involving meat processors, who say they are now unfairly restricted in what they can use in their products, and a number of vocal consumers, who contend that the regulation would allow meat companies to mislead shoppers. The Agriculture Department has sometimes sided with the consumers in the dispute and sometimes with the producers. Ground bone is a byproduct - invisible to the naked eye -that results when scraps of meat are removed from beef and hog carcasses by machine. Under the current Agriculture Department regulation, ground-up bone, mixed with scraps of ground-up meat, can replace up to 20 percent of the meat in hot dogs, bologna, liverwurst and a host of other processed meats, including canned chili con carne and spaghetti with meat sauce. However, any product containing ground bone must be clearly labeled, and the exact percentage of bone must be prominently stated.

headline.main: PROPOSAL WOULD ALTER LABELING OF GROUND BONE

docs.snippet: 'Ruggles of Red Gap' For something disarming and different in the field of gentle satire, catch Leo McCarey's ''Ruggles of Red Gap'' (1935), showing Tuesday at midnight on Channel 13. In this fond, funny serving of Americana, an imported British b...
docs.lead_paragraph: 'Ruggles of Red Gap' For something disarming and different in the field of gentle satire, catch Leo McCarey's ''Ruggles of Red Gap'' (1935), showing Tuesday at midnight on Channel 13. In this fond, funny serving of Americana, an imported British butler reluctantly, then proudly adjusts to the crude but hearty spirit of a turn-of-the-century frontier town. A sporting cast headed by Charles Laughton in the title role, Charles Ruggles (no connection with the title), Mary Boland, Leila Hyams, ZaSu Pitts and the leathery Maude Eburne, perform winningly under McCarey's flavorsome direction.

docs.snippet: Mr. and Mrs. Jack Rosenthal of Searingtown, L.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Barbara Ann Rosenthal, to Martin Birnbaum, son of Mr. and Mrs. Oscar Birnbaum of Manhasset Hills, L.I.    Miss Rosenthal is vice president of J.R. E...
docs.lead_paragraph: Mr. and Mrs. Jack Rosenthal of Searingtown, L.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Barbara Ann Rosenthal, to Martin Birnbaum, son of Mr. and Mrs. Oscar Birnbaum of Manhasset Hills, L.I. Miss Rosenthal is vice president of J.R. Equities Inc., a New York real-estate management company of which her father is president. Mr. Birnbaum, associate director of development at the American Cancer Society, New York City Division, graduated from Temple University. Mr. Birnbaum's marriage ended in divorce.

headline.main: Martin Birnbaum Fiance Of Barbara A. Rosenthal

docs.snippet: IN book publishing, spring magically starts at the end of January and runs past the summer solstice, and decisions about what will be published in that time have usually been made several years in advance. Therefore, I asked some top editors and p...
docs.lead_paragraph: IN book publishing, spring magically starts at the end of January and runs past the summer solstice, and decisions about what will be published in that time have usually been made several years in advance. Therefore, I asked some top editors and publishers who are already deciding what we will be reading a few years hence how the future of publishing is shaping up for that eventual judge of all the writers' efforts and publishers' editorial meetings: the American reader. Their responses were generally hopeful - at least about some of their ''we're proud to publish'' books. Yet at this time of economic recession they were chary about predicting the response of readers in general. Caution was the watchword; lists have been pared and appear to have few ''fillers.'' And I heard far less than in other seasons about page-turners, good reads and other euphemisms for the ordinary.

byline.original: By HERBERT MITGANG, Herbert Mitgang, cultural correspondent for the New York Times has two books, ''Mister Lincoln'' (a play) and ''The Montauk Fault''(in paperback) on the spring 1982 lists.uary and runs past the summer solstice, and decisions about what will be published in that time have usually been made several years in advance. Therefore, I asked some top editors and publishers who are already deciding what we will be reading a few years hence how the future of publishing is shaping up for that eventual judge of all the writers' efforts and publishers' editorial meetings: the American reader

docs.snippet: --------------------------------------------------------------------  Allen Churchill is the author of ''The Great White Way'' and ''The Theatrical 20's.'' By ALLEN CHURCHILL   Talk of the demolition of two or more established Broadway theaters to...
docs.lead_paragraph: -------------------------------------------------------------------- Allen Churchill is the author of ''The Great White Way'' and ''The Theatrical 20's.'' By ALLEN CHURCHILL Talk of the demolition of two or more established Broadway theaters to make way for a glossy supra-hotel brings particular pangs to the nostalgia-conscious. As an author who has researched and written two books about what used to be called the Great White Way, I can easily shut my eyes and visualize today's theater district back in 1900, when no theaters at all stood above 42d Street. The area was then no more than a neighborhood, largely filled by cheap boarding houses for aspiring actors and vaudeville acts between bookings - ''at liberty,'' it was called. One who passed hot summers on these boarding house stoops was Will Rogers, before he was tapped for glory in the ''Ziegfeld Follies.''

headline.main: RECALLING THE HEYDAY OF THE GREAT WHITE WAY

docs.snippet: All-Star Cast Several programs this week will salute the 100th anniversary of Franklin @D. Roosevelt's birth, and one of them will offer a television first: four living American Presidents interviewed on a single program. On ABC's ''F.D.R.,'' to b...
docs.lead_paragraph: All-Star Cast Several programs this week will salute the 100th anniversary of Franklin @D. Roosevelt's birth, and one of them will offer a television first: four living American Presidents interviewed on a single program. On ABC's ''F.D.R.,'' to be broadcast Friday from 8 to 11 P.M., President Ronald Reagan and former Presidents Jimmy Carter, Gerald Ford and Richard Nixon will express opinions of their White House predecessor. David Brinkley will be the interviewer-anchorman for the retrospective news program, which will also document President Roosevelt's life and career in film footage and will include additional new interviews with relatives, colleagues, friends and political foes. ''F.D.R.'' is the work of 90 ABC News staff members. Pamela Hill, executive producer, says that the program's aim is ''to assess the continuing and enduring impact Roosevelt made on American life to see what he did that still affects us today in both domestic and foreign affairs. We aren't taking the view that he's an icon.''
